review_title: Good and bad but a great team
pros: Supportive manager, great fun with my volunteer team, loved having responsibility for the shop on my days and there are some really lovely regular customers. Always felt supported by my store manager and area manager, get to have experience of other stores too which was fun to do. Lots of possibilities for career progression and encourage to do this which was fantastic!
cons:
It is hard work, make no mistake! Customers have no awareness of how little space you have to store stuff and just bring in loads of stuff at once and expect you to be grateful for what is often something not fit for purpose. There are many who use the charity shop when they can’t be bothered going to the dump so they give you their rubbish and you’re expected to process it. 
There is a LOT of lone working when staff do not turn up, this is fine for quieter moments but in busy periods it is exhausting. You often have no chance to have a lunch break, or really any break at all. There is a LOT of heavy lifting, more than any other job I’ve been in and that’s saying something! Imagine delivery day in retail at your busiest time of year, then imagine you have no staff other than YOU and the delivery does not stop coming all day. Plus it’s in loose bags, or completely unpackaged, and you have to work the till, and process returns (yes people can return to charity shops), make up rotas, answer the phone, be the security for the shop, answer the back door to the rag man/the van doing uplift for the distribution centre/the binmen, don’t forget the banking has to go round every day too and you’re not meant to close the shop to do this... so you can see it’s not the easiest job in those ways. 
That being said, I do miss my job there because as crazy as those moments were it was a happy environment and the good days were great!

review_title: No personality and no upper management interest or support
pros:
Some great people
Great cause
Flexible working
cons:
The office runs a 'hotdesk' environment so many employees at head office never get to sit at the same desk or build relationships with their extended teams. Because the company offers flexible working, the 9-5 staff often take the same desks daily then those who start at 9.30/10 are often left to sit on different floors so it takes a long time to understand the company, department and your teams way of working.
In the year I was there, I never spoke to the CE, despite him often sitting in the same open plan room. I realise this is a big organisation, but I don't feel he (or his senior leadership team) take enough time to find out what the people below are working on.
The amount of structure changes and policies for policy's sake are infuriating. As a marketing specialist, I felt my role was just to fill in briefs which were then ignored by various departments.

review_title: All aspects of the job from receiving donations through sorting, hanging, tagging and steaming and pricing.
pros:
Meeting all sorts of people from every walk of life. 
We never know what will come through the door as a donation.
Serving someone who has found something they had been looking for, for ages. Seeing their smile as they walk out the door with, what they see as an absolute bargain is a great feeling.
Being able to help someone.
In-store discount of 20%.
cons:
We accept donations from bereaved families whereby they just empty the contents of wardrobes and dressers into sack and drop off. This is a sad occasion and the donation can be quite smelly.
We cannot accept a huge donation as our shop is only small with limited window space and storage.

pros: Lots of opportunities to get key skills
cons: Didn’t get any till service

pros: Nice people, great to work in a charity shop.  Store manager was fantastic
cons:
After two months was summoned to a meeting.  Hours were to be reduced from 21 a week to 13 in April.  13 is significant as it made Sunday a compulsory working day.  Tried every possible way to negotiate on this matter.  NO RESPONSES at all to any letters or emails.
In the three months I worked there was sent as acting manager to 5 stores.  They knew I could do the job.  Store manager was really supportive.  Even offered to go down to 14 hours so that manager and myself could work weekends fairly.  NO!  
Having failed to respond to anything - including writing all over my contract and even a personal letter to Javed Khan sent recorded delivery - it is ironic that they acknowledged my resignation within 2 days and had advertised two posts (one 7 hours per week and one 6 hours) within three days.  They claim to support the vulnerable - but they have bullied me out of a job.
Also was getting paid 7 hours pay, but the working day with unpaid lunchtimes, store opening and closing unpaid in own time -etc, was nearer NINE HOURS!

job_title: Retail Store Manager in Liverpool, England
pros: A very worthwhile cause. I love the concept of making a difference. Volunteers give their time freely and are an asset just don't abuse their time.
cons: Poor upper management. You often lone work and work through your unpaid lunch hour constantly have to stay later to cash up they should allow you to close 15 minutes earlier to do cashing up. Have to sort out your own cover for holidays and I have even had to change my holidays as there's no cover. Regional management have no compassion for illness or if you have problems at home. There's a high level of stress related sickness in my area but your accused of being lazy or trouble makers instead of being given support. Lots of bullying tactics stemming from Upper management and there is no confidentiality from Upper management and they are often heard berating and bad mouthing  managers to other staff members but people are too scared to speak out. Volunteers are often misused being pressured into opening and closing stores by management saying the store will have to close yet they are cutting sales assistants hours down.

pros: Meeting customers.  Working with volunteers.  Decent rate of pay.
cons: Health & safety.  Store room was a health hazard, no direct means of escape in event of fire!  Rotas never done until the week before so you couldn't plan anything.  Told (not asked) to cover other stores, the overtime was nice but I never got travelling expenses as the online claiming was too time consuming.  Expected to stay behind every day for 20 or so mins to input the  daily sales and gift aid figures.  This might not seem too bad but it adds up to extra 3 hrs unpaid work each week.  I could go on, especially about the Manager whom even the customers think is rude, but I'll leave it at that and I'm glad I moved on.  I think with Barnardos it's  a lot do do with the individual store and manager so maybe I just wasn't lucky.   The one I was in did have a high staff turn over and volunteers didn't stay, so that says it all.  Good luck if you chose to work there.

review_title: I progressed throughout my time there and met some great local people. Pleasure to work there.

I love seeing old friends there.
cons: You always have one or two co-workers who thought they ere the ones in charge due to being there for a considerable amount of time. The problem there is they're on the same level as you. Sometimes our manager would have to sort arguments out and it'd distract us from the work. That was the only real problem there.

pros:
- lovely regular customers

cons:
-Barnardo's treat their retail staff terribly. I was a Store Associate and although I only worked 4 days a week, I was more exhausted and stressed than now, when I work 5 days a week and commute for 2 hours a day.

-The senior management put immense pressure on staff to reach unrealistic targets

-Lack of support. I didnt feel like I was treated as an actual human being. Sick? Still got to work.  Mental breakdown? Still got to come into work. I ended up having to quit on the spot because my mental health problems got so bad because of the stress of work.

-WORKING 9 HOURS A DAY FOR 7 HOURS OF PAY. Seriously, how can you only be paid for 7 hours when you HAVE to get in the shop before 9am to open for 9am, you NEVER get a lunch break and then you have to spend a good 30 mins after the shop closing to deal with paperwork etc. PAY YOUR STAFF FOR THE WORK THEY DO AND ENSURE THEY GET BREAKS. It's breaking the law if you dont.

Talks a very good game but underneath doesn’t care about staff, simply make the money and stay quiet is her thought process. So many managers SAs and volunteers left because of this. It’s a really horrible place to work. No support, go home worrying about your shop . I’m desperate to leave !

Multi-tasking includes recruiting volunteers, training others, health & safety, lots of office-work, knowledgeable pricing, marketing, merchandising, generating stock, sorting, customer service, providing cover for other shops, attending meetings, etc. A lot to ask for "breadline" wages.

pros: As a mum with some daytime hours to spare, I decided to volunteer in the local Barnados shop in Stourbridge. It is a pleasure to give my time to help such a lovely bunch of people run such a nice shop and raise money for disadvantaged children. I definitely recommend volunteering in this shop.

review_title: A nice retail job with great staff and volunteers
pros: The staff and volunteers in the area are all lovely and so supportive, it feels like being part of a huge family. You meet a lot of people and there are of course some you get on with more than others, but there are many that I consider friends. The work usually isn't hard, but it can be quite monotonous. there's some heavy lifting and manual labour (like heaving 50 bin bags of clothes up a flight of stairs) but it's not every day. The area manager is really helpful, if you have a problem she will try and fix it, and she visits the shops in the area quite a lot to see how we could improve (although the old area manager we never saw and was impossible to get a hold of, I have no idea what he actually did all day). Both staff and volunteers get a 20% discount on stock that is already cheap, so that is a bonus. You have almost free reign of merchandising the shop and displays too, which is great if you like being creative. Each shop has its own personality.
cons:
Barnardos are hugely understaffed which means staff have to cover other shops, taking a valuable pair of hands away from their own shop. The paid members of staff also aren't paid for the hours they actually work - I realise it's a charity but people have to make money to live, and if you say that it's a 35 hour contract I expect to work 35 hours. My store is open 9-5.30 every day, but we have to arrive at around 8.30 to open up and get the cash in the till, and it takes another 20 mins or half an hour to cash up in the evening. This is a 9.5 hour day, and we are only paid for 7 of those hours. Most people only take a half an hour lunch break due to the workload, but even if we took a whole hour and 2 15 min breaks, that's still an hour we aren't being paid for. 
A lot of the time, especially for a new store with no volunteers, A member of staff is on their own for many hours or even all day. Personally I don't feel safe doing this but I have no choice as its not a good enough excuse to close the shop, even though there are shoplifters and really anyone could walk into the shop. A few months ago a customer actually hit another manager in the area. Also there's the normal retail stuff like getting verbally abused by customers on a daily basis, mainly because it's against company policy to reduce items. But for every horrible customer there's 20 nice ones.

job_title: Digital Team Member in Barkingside, England
pros:
Away from senior leaders you'll find some of the most inspirational staff around - all of them worthy of the highest praise.

Barnardo's is a fantastic cause although since the current CEO joined appears to have seriously lost its way.
cons:
Barnardo's is currently suffering a 'Digital Transformation'.

The vast majority of the previous IT staff (50+ people) have been made redundant with the management having little idea of the skills or responsibilities that have been forced out of the organisation.  This has created enormous holes in domain and organisational knowledge which will affect operational stability going forward.  To compound this issue a significant number of those who were able to transfer to new positions, have understandably decided to leave of their own free will, due to the inept, blame shifting leadership now in place.

A large number of contractors have been used to fill some of the gaps created by those leaving as well as the positions required by the new Digital Team (all earning industry day rate) - this has been at huge expense to the charity.  Their expertise is no substitute for the experience that has now left, meaning that working within the Digital/old IS team Team has become a high stress, chaotic affair.

Now so many people have left, there is no turning back and since so much money has been spent to this point, I suspect it will continue until there are serious changes at the top (hopefully extending as far as the Board of Trustees who have allowed this mess to go unchallenged).

If you're looking in to one of the digital jobs, at this point in time, just walk on by.

 Area managers sit on their backsides doing nothing then panic when results have to be in.
Upper bosses don't care about the workers who actually do the hard work.

CEO is never seen out and about. 
Trying to act as a company with non of the protection or working ethics in place to protect its workers.
Now that they insist on recruiting from out side the company (for upper management) no one has any Idea how hard it is to run a charity shop, as isn't like normal retail.

job_title: Retail Store Manager in Birmingham, England
pros: Fantastic volunteers and some great staff working under intense pressure
cons: Too many to mention, but the total lack of respect for the retail field is paramount

job_title: Retail Sales Assistant in London, England
pros: It is a charity helping children, so it's a great cause to work hard for.
cons:
Serious lack of professionalism.
Shops are meant to have at least 2 working staff, but that almost never happens.
Therefore, it is extremely hard to take your annual leave (which is only the minimum set by the law). It also means that there's no one to cover for you at the shop if you're away/sick. 
Of course, it means the shops will be untidy and unorganised and some donations will not be sorted for days or sometimes weeks.

While it's great to have people with disabilities working at the shop, the staff is requested to train them and run the shop at the same time, even if you're on your own.

As someone stated here before, you are getting paid for 7 hours a day, yet I worked in 2 shops and did covers in many others and the operation hours are 8-8.5 hours per day, where you get a 1h unpaid lunch break. Obviously, when you're on your own you cannot close the shop and you cannot have your lunch! 

On top of that, to drain staff's energy even further, you are expected to take as much overtime as you're asked, even if you work part-time. my colleague works only 21h a week, and she was forced to take an extra day, and her working days pattern was changed every week.
There's lack of understanding and professionalism from the management who simply do not understand what happens in our day-to-day job.

I will not recommend you to work here, and like many of my co-workers I have already applied for other positions elsewhere.
